TEXT: e1: Health insurance companies should not cover treatments in complementary medicine
e2: unless the promised effect and its medical benefit have been concretely proven.
e3: Yet this very proof is lacking in most cases.
e4: Patients do often report relief of their complaints after such treatments.
e5: But as long as it is unclear as to how this works, the funds should rather be spent on therapies where one knows with certainty.

MISSING INFORMATION 1: It is not always proven whether treatments in complementary medicine have a medical benefit.
CN RELATIONS 1: treatments, medical benefit (HasA)/treatments in complimentary medicine, medical benefit (NotHasA)/medical benefit, proven (NotHasProperty)
MISSING INFORMATION 2: Health insurance companies only pay for treatments with a proven medical benefit.

MISSING INFORMATION 1: Treatments that lead to a relief of complaints should be covered by health insurance companies.

MISSING INFORMATION 1: It is not known with certainty how treatments in complementary medicine work.

MISSING INFORMATION 1: Being relieved of complaints after a treatment means there is a proof of the effect of the treatment.

MISSING INFORMATION 1: One should know with certainty how a treatment works.
